I studied for around 200 for a semester (so 2000 for 5 years). I guess I understand now why the top point why Germany is among the most livable countries in the world is its "almost" free education (besides health care).
It is more of a question of how education is paid for. In the US, for post-high school education, students and their parents are expected to directly carry a lot of the burden for education costs. State schools here cost about $10k/year in tuition; private schools can cost upwards of $40k/year (for reference, this is something of a recent development; I went to school in 2003-2007 at Vanderbilt and tuition was about $28k ostensibly).
There's a few caveats, though; first off, scholarships. I only graduated with $12k in debt after going to Vanderbilt, which is one of the best universities in the world. I paid $28k/year in tuition, and got $25k/year in scholarships. Most private schools have major financial aid programs; most people don't pay the full cost of tuition.
Secondly, there's the fact that in Germany, education is subsidized by the state. This means that rather than your education being "almost free", it is simply being charged in a different way - namely, by taxing you more. This means that everyone in Germany has to pay for college, even if they themselves don't go to college. German income tax rates are 6 percentage points higher than they are in the US, and capital tax rates are 20 percentage points higher. That's on top of a 19% VAT. The US has no federal VAT at all; some states (like the one I live in) don't even have VATs.
Thirdly, Americans are considerably richer than Germans - we earn more and keep more of our income.
As they say, there ain't no such thing as a free lunch.

Im not sure if its prudent to dismiss studies like this out of hand. Do you have a background in research and oncology that allows you to attest to the validity of this study?
I have a background in biology and statistics (I'm a biomedical engineer by training). However, that's irrelevant in this case; anyone with even a basic understanding of science and statistics can see the flaws here.
It is prudent to dismiss studies like this out of hand, especially when their methodological flaws are as obvious as this one's are.
Meat consumption is *predicted*, not directly measured. They adjusted it using confounding variables, as noted here:
Country- and sex-specific calibration models were used to obtain individual predicted values of dietary exposure for all participants.
This is already a problem because they're introducing *more* variables which already correlate with these things!
They don't note that they weighted the data by the weight of the participants, and indeed, it is improper in the first place to use a broad range of weights because weight is already known to be a risk factor in these things.
On top of that, as noted by the study, smoking was more common in people who ate more red meat, and smoking is the biggest risk factor for esophageal cancer!
The study says absolutely nothing of value whatsoever. They failed to do the most basic things which are necessary to measure the results they are looking for.
If you want to do measurements of this, what you should do - the *proper* observational experimental design - would be to take people who have the same BMI and who exercise as often, and who don't smoke, and then look at that group of people and look at whether people who consume more red meat *within that group* develop more cancer.
This is the correct experimental design because rather than trying to manipulate your data, you are instead isolating a number of variables from consideration - you can't really properly adjust for BMI, smoking, ect. because you don't know the exact magnitude of those risk factors and they are much larger than the risk factor for consuming red meat. As such, the correct way of dealing with them is to just eliminate them as variables altogether; if you're just looking at people between, say, 21 and 23 BMI, who don't smoke and who exercise regularly, you're going to get better results because you've eliminated a number of variables from consideration which are known risk factors (sedenary lifestyle, obesity, and smoking).
This doesn't require any sort of advanced knowledge of the discipline; it requires a basic understanding of experimental science. You should always eliminate variables rather than try to do post-hoc adjustments to compensate for them, because in real life, you don't know how much of an impact these variables have, there is always measurement error, and in many cases, the risk factor is so large that any small variation by chance in the underlying rates will have a large impact on your estimated risk. If your smoking rate is measured as 10%, and the risk of cancer goes up 1000% from smoking, then a measurement error of 2% in the smoking rate will result in an enormous change in estimated risk because most of the people in your sample who got cancer got it from smoking.

I think a lot of people forget that D D is a game. If you look at the very first D D book - the one published in 1974 - it barely spends any time at all explaining what D D is. It is pretty much entirely devoted to the rules, and hardly explains what roleplaying is at all.
Older editions had a somewhat different mentality than newer ones, but the idea that it was all about outthinking/outwitting the GM isn't really correct. 1st Edition AD D's DMG certainly took on an air of condescending superiority (oh lordy, did it), but it still talked about making things fair for the players, avoiding spoiling things by throwing in random monsters for no good reason, ect.
As the 1st edition AD D PHB, written in 1978, notes:
Each individual campaign has its awn distinct properties and "flavor". A good Dungeon Master will most certainly make each game a surpassing challenge for his or her players. Treasure and experience gained must be taken at great risk or by means of utmost cleverness only. If the game is not challenging, if advancement is too speedy, then it becomes staid and boring. Conversely, a game can be too deadly and become just as boring, for who enjoys endlessly developing new characters to march off into oblivion in a single night of dungeon adventuring?!
...
ADVANCED DUNGEONS DRAGONS is a world. Of course, this world is not complete. It needs organizers and adventurers to order and explore it. It needs you! A fantasy role playing game is an exercise in imagination and personal creativity. The organizer of the campaign, the Dungeon Master, must use the system to devise an individual and unique world. Into this world of weird monsters, strange peoples, multitudinous states, and fabulous treasures of precious items and powerful magic stride fearless adventurers - you and your fellow players. Inexperienced and of but small power at first, by dint of hard fighting and clever deeds, these adventurers advance in ability to become forces to be reckoned with - high priests or priestesses, lords, wizards and arch-magi, master thieves. The abilities of each adventurer are fixed, but even such characteristics as strength, intelligence, and wisdom are mutable in a fantasy world. By means of group co-operation and individuol achievement, an adventurer can become ever more powerful. Even death loses much of its sting, for often the character can be resurrected, or reincarnated. And should that fail there is always the option to begin again with a new character. Thus ADVANCED DUNGEONS DRAGONS is, as are most role playing games, open-ended. There is no "winner", no final objective, and the campaign grows and changes as it matures.
D D has always been designed as a system which challenges the players. But the goal is not for the DM to "win" or for the players to "win", it is, as noted above, an exercise in imagination and personal creativity. Challenge was (and is) seen as essential because, without challenge, the players can simply do the same things over and over and and always succeed. For many players, stuff gets boring if things are too easy, and D D has always been intended to challenge players with the task before them.
2nd edition AD D dropped the condensation present in Gygax's writing in the 1st Edition AD D books. The DMG does mention that it is primarily directed at DMs, but the reason is noted to be that it is intended to improve player enjoyment - hidden rules allow the player a sense of discovery, as if they know everything in the monster manual and DMG inside and out, it means that they are going to lose any sense of wonder of discovery at finding these items or encountering these foes. I think one of the flaws in many people's thinking about D D is that they don't understand the core conceit.
The core conceit of D D is that the players are a group of adventurers who are overcoming great odds in order to succeed in some heroic quest. This is why challenge is seen as so important in D D - because if heroes aren't challenged, their victory doesn't seem so sweet.
I think once you understand that, D D makes a lot more sense. It's nature as a shared experience is that of a group of adventurers overcoming a series of challenges and emerging as victorious against great odds. The DM helps create this experience, the world around them, the odds set before them - and subtly slants them in the favor of the player. Subtly is sort of key there; at its core, to some extent D D is a power fantasy, but it is meant to be a power fantasy which makes the player feel like they've overcome an obstacle, not like success was simply handed to them.
This is why some people who don't really understand D D see it as competitive - because they see the DM putting obstacles in their path, and see it as the DM trying to stop them. But if you understand the core conceit of D D, it is not that the obstacles are there to stop the player, but for the players to overcome them.
People who don't buy into the core conceit of D D are unlikely to enjoy it very much, or to really grok what it is about.

Controls should always be as simple as possible. In a FPS, for instance, you reload by pressing a single key, and automatically reload when your ammo is out. Indeed, some games don't even have reloading, making them even simpler. Some games don't even have limited ammunition, like Overwatch.
Introducing reloading is not something which should be done without thinking; it should have a purpose. Reloading, from a mechanical perspective, means you cannot attack continuously; you must take a break from it. In some games, this is a good thing - in Overwatch, for instance, it means that you cannot lay down an endless stream of suppressive fire. If the enemy can bait you into wasting your shots, they have a window of opportunity to attack while you cannot or while your ammo is depleted so you can't lay down as much fire. Some characters - like D. Va and Reinhardt - don't have limited clip sizes, while others, like Orisa, have very large ones. Others, like Roadhog, have very small ones. This alters how these characters play, because Roadhog has to make every shot count while Orisa, D. Va, and Reinhardt can attack continuously without consequence.
But it would be retarded to make it so that there was a complex key sequence required to reload a gun. Why make it more complex than pressing R? There's no actual reason for that; it is just pointless complexity. Likewise, they make you automatically reload when your clip is empty because there's no reason not to reload at that point.
They don't limit total ammo counts because that would require people to run off and replenish their ammunition, which would screw up the flow of gameplay.
On the other hand, in a game like DOOM, you have a bunch of weapons. You can fire your guns until they're empty, and can run around and pick up ammo from the ground. DOOM is all about the run-and-gun, with you laying down fire constantly and no interruptions for reloading (though some weapons, like the Super Shotgun, have a much lower rate of fire which is represented by a reloading animation). DOOM's gameplay doesn't want you to waste time reloading, it wants constant action in fights, not you running off to hide like a pansy. So there's no reloading.
Stutter-stepping is a basic form of movement. There's no reason why it shouldn't be automated. If you want to stutter-step outside of the "perfect" rate of it, you can do so manually, but if you just want to fall back while firing continuously at maximum rate of fire, or move forward while firing continuously, it should be automated.
Simple controls mean people's characters do exactly what they want them to do, which is a good thing. The goal isn't to make people's control of their charcters difficult, it is to make them play correctly. The decision should be over whether or not stutter-stepping is appropriate in the situation at hand.

The point I was making was that big data makes that uncertainty and usual lack of foresight when it comes to horizontal integration of companies much less of a factor. When you can see what businesses consumers are searching for, how they're talking about it, how they're sharing it and how they're using it, you can start to map trends.
Economy of scale has always been a thing and will always be a thing. Incumbents in a market tend to have an advantage for this very reason; they've already invested in the capital and they already benefit a lot from economy of scale.
But the reality is that if some other search engine did what Google does, but better, people would switch over to it. Indeed, the cost of switching in terms of switching search engines is very low. The cost of switching on Facebook is higher if you've got a lot of friends on Facebook, but if you don't really use Facebook, the cost of switching is negligible. And indeed, I know lots of people who barely use Facebook or who don't use it at all (I check mine maybe like three times a year). Undermining these monopolies is actually really easy now in many ways, because all they have to do to get away from you is click on another website.
In a traditional space, it is very hard for your audience to completely abandon you overnight; it takes time for people to build stores and factories and suchlike. But on the Internet, there's just one website; someone who builds a new website can eat your lunch in a day because the physical investment to be everywhere simply is not as high. The Internet is actually really friendly to low-capital startups, because you don't need physical spaces so much.
Having lots of data is no different from any other form of capital, and in the end, making predictions requires extrapolation from data.

Yes. You should always make your command inputs as simple as possible.

Game design 101: never make your game's controls unnecessarily complicated. Your game's controls should be as simple as possible.
Mechanical complexity is pretty much inevitable in a game like a MOBA. Trying to avoid the pointless introduction thereof is important, as MOBAs are already really complex games with a lot going on. There's no reason not to automate it; it makes the game more accessible and allows people to spend more focus on things that really matter and are interesting.
